newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU Commission lessens oil product duty increases.
newsitem.headline: EU Commission lessens oil product duty increases.

text.p: The European Commission has modified proposals to raise minimum excise duties on oil products such as gasoline and diesel. The increases will be less than those first proposed.

According to a new draft, the minimum levy on gasoline will rise from 337 European currency units to 417 ecus per 1,000 litres in 1998 rather than the 450 ecus under an earlier proposal, a Commission official told Reuters.
The levy will rise to 450 ecus in the year 2000 and 500 ecus in 2002.
Diesel would be taxed a minimum 310 ecus per 1,000 litres in 1998, 343 ecus in 2000 and 393 ecus in 2002. The current rate is 245 ecus. The minimum initially proposed for 1998 was 343 ecus.
Those are also the proposed and current minima for kerosene.

Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) would be taxed a minimum 141 ecus per 1,000 kilogrammes in 1998, to rise to 174 ecus and 224 in 2000 and 2002. The current rate is 100 ecus. The Commission had initially proposed 174 ecus in 1998.
Natural gas, for which there is currently no EU minimum rate, would be subject to a minimum levy of 2.9 ecus per gigajoule in 1998, to be followed by 3.5 ecus in 2000 and 4.5 ecus in 2002.

The rates above are applicable to motor fuels in general. The Commission has not changed its proposal regarding reduced rates for fuels used in agriculture and public transport as well as the levels applicable to heating fuels, the Commission source said.

The proposal, which is fiercely opposed by European industry, is expected to be approved by the Commission earlier next month, possibly next week. EU finance ministers will have the last word on the issue which requires unanimous voting. -- Amelia Torres 322 2876841
